entry.title: Fix Ryujinx after the 6.3.1 Update
entry.summary: Guide to Fix Ryujinx after the 6.3.1 Update: WARNING SKIP STEP 1 IF YOU DON'T WANT TO LOOSE YOUR SAVED GAMES 3a. Open emulator (RetroBat\emulators\ryujinx\Ryujinx.exe), it will say no prod, title keys (if not go to the next step) 3b. ryujinx will promt for a update, do it (its safe), no promt? goto help>check update Download new prod title keys at: https://prodkeys.net/ryujinx-prod-keys-13/
entry.content:
Guide to Fix Ryujinx after the 6.3.1 Update:

WARNING SKIP STEP 1 IF YOU DON'T WANT TO LOOSE YOUR SAVED GAMES

  1. Remove the portable directory (RetroBat\emulators\ryujinx\portable) and create a new one (empty)
  1. Remove \RetroBat\saves\switch\ryujinx folder (if your not sure, make a copy of that directory first and name to ryujinx.bak)

3a. Open emulator (RetroBat\emulators\ryujinx\Ryujinx.exe), it will say no prod, title keys (if not go to the next step)

3b. ryujinx will promt for a update, do it (its safe), no promt? goto help>check update

  1. Download new prod title keys at: https://prodkeys.net/ryujinx-prod-keys-13/

entry.title: Updating to v.6.3.1
entry.summary: This update for RetroBat includes some key changes related to 'save' locations that you need to be aware of. These actions should be done AFTER the upgrade and BEFORE you try to launch any games. Move RPCS3 dev_hdd0 folder to saves\ps3\rpcs3\hdd_0 (you need to cut/paste when upgrading, if you want to keep the current folder in emulator directory, delete saves\ps3\rpcs3\hdd_0 folder) Move PPSSPP memstick folder to saves\psp (you need to cut/paste when upgrading) Move CEMU mlc01 folder to saves\wiiu\cemu\mlc01 (you need to cut/paste when upgrading, if you want to keep the current folder in emulator directory, delete saves\wiiu\cemu\mlc01 folder) Move…
entry.content:
This update for RetroBat includes some key changes related to 'save' locations that you need to be aware of.

These actions should be done AFTER the upgrade and BEFORE you try to launch any games.

From the RetroBat change log:

Move RPCS3 dev_hdd0 folder to saves\ps3\rpcs3\hdd_0 (you need to cut/paste when upgrading, if you want to keep the current folder in emulator directory, delete saves\ps3\rpcs3\hdd_0 folder)

Move PPSSPP memstick folder to saves\psp (you need to cut/paste when upgrading)

Move CEMU mlc01 folder to saves\wiiu\cemu\mlc01 (you need to cut/paste when upgrading, if you want to keep the current folder in emulator directory, delete saves\wiiu\cemu\mlc01 folder)

Move XENIA and XENIA-CANARY content path to saves\xbox360\xenia (you need to cut/paste when upgrading, if you want to keep the current folder in emulator directory, delete saves\xbox360\xenia folder)

Move Ryujinx portable path to saves\switch\ryujinx (you need to cut/paste when upgrading, if you want to keep the current folder in emulator directory, delete saves\switch\ryujinx folder)

Move Vita3K content path to saves\psvita\vita3k as default(you can still use a custom path)

Recommended Steps:
PS3:
Move \RetroBat\emulators\rpcs3\dev_hdd0 to \RetroBat\saves\ps3\rpcs3\dev_hdd0

PSP:
Move \RetroBat\emulators\ppsspp\memstick to \RetroBat\saves\psp\memstick

WiiU:
Move \RetroBat\emulators\cemu\mlc01 to \RetroBat\saves\wiiu\cemu\mlc01 Xbox360: (Only move folders with names similar to "58410901" as these are where the save games are stored. For example, folders such as 'cache' 'config' or 'patches' are part of the emulator and show be left where they are)
Move \RetroBat\emulators\xenia\ to \RetroBat\saves\xbox360\xenia\ Note: Xenia and Xenia-Canary share they save saves folder.

Switch:
Move \RetroBat\emulators\ryujinx\portable to \RetroBat\saves\switch\ryujinx\portable

PSVita: (Optional but recommended)
1. Close RetroBat and browse to \RetroBat\emulators\vita3k\ and run Vita3K.exe
2. Click in the Vita3K window and go to 'Configuration' then 'Settings'
3. Click on the 'Emulator' tab then click 'Change Emulator Path'
4. Browse to \RetroBat\saves\psvita\vita3k and click 'Select Folder
5. Now click on 'Save' then 'Close'
6. You can now close the Vita3K emulator
7. Now move (cut/paste) the following folders from \RetroBat\emulators\vita3k\ to \RetroBat\saves\psvita\vita3k\
gro0
grw0
host0
imc0
os0
pd0
sa0
sd0
tm0
ud0
uma0
ur0
ux0
vd0
vs0
xmc0
8. All done!

entry.title: Naomi 2 (naomi2)
entry.content:
for Batocera and Retrobat


The Sega NAOMI 2 is an arcade board developed by Sega and is a successor to Sega NAOMI hardware. It was originally released in 2000. Since it uses similar NAOMI architecture (but significantly beefed up), it is also fully backwards compatible with its predecessor.

The NAOMI 2 is significantly more powerful than the NAOMI, including a dual CPU setup, new TL GPU, dual rasterizer GPU, increased memory, and faster bandwidth. This leads to games with much more polygons than a NAOMI game, rendered at much faster speeds, while the new TL GPU adds advanced lighting and particle effects. It was also more affordable than the very expensive (and difficult to program) Sega Hikaru arcade system that preceded it. The NAOMI 2 was nevertheless more powerful than home systems at the time.

As with the NAOMI, the NAOMI 2 was also available in GD-ROM and Satellite Terminal variants. It was Sega's last proprietary arcade system board; subsequent Sega arcade boards have been based on console and PC hardware.

The package includes:

12 games (~2 GB)

Go to download   

How to install:
Drag and drop the "naomi2" folder into the 'roms' directory and Enjoy!

Fix for RetroBat: Bios popup when booting https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1Gk8KWp_SB_lhFCH8ELlUxJ3Wkjc6jkVm?usp=sharing  

List of games:
  1. beachspi - Beach Spikers: Virtua Beach Volleyball
  2. clubkrt - Club Kart: European Session
  3. initdexp - Initial D: Arcade Stage
  4. initdv2j - Initial D: Arcade Stage Ver. 2
  5. initdv3e - Initial D: Version 3
  6. kingrt66 - The King of Route 66
  7. soulsurf - Soul Surfer
  8. vf4cart - Virtua Fighter 4
  9. vf4evoct - Virtua Fighter 4: Evolution
  10. vf4tuned - Virtua Fighter 4: Final Tuned
  11. vstrik3c - Virtua Striker 3
  12. wldrider - Wild Riders

entry.title: General - Startup
entry.summary: On the first start, there's no Windows file caching yet. What is taking so long is the "fileexist" test. When you have a fast SSD or USB drive, or once Windows has cached the file system, it's really fast. But, If you have an old mechanical HDD it takes longer. Also, some themes can take longer to load than others. One thing you can try is going into the Developer Options screen and enable 'Parse Gamelists Only' This should make it only read the gamelist.xml in each ROM folder rather than scanning all ROMs. If at any point you add…
entry.content:
On the first start, there's no Windows file caching yet. What is taking so long is the "fileexist" test. When you have a fast SSD or USB drive, or once Windows has cached the file system, it's really fast. But, If you have an old mechanical HDD it takes longer. Also, some themes can take longer to load than others.

One thing you can try is going into the Developer Options screen and enable 'Parse Gamelists Only' This should make it only read the gamelist.xml in each ROM folder rather than scanning all ROMs. If at any point you add your own games, you will need to temporarily turn the option off and restart RetroBat, so that it can scan for the new games at startup.

entry.title: The One Build - Install
entry.summary: The extraction speed will depend on a few factors: CPU power, as it will need to perform the decompression algorithm. Hard drive performance. Obviously an SSD or NVMe drive will be quicker than a traditional spinning drive. However it will also be slower if you just have a single drive, as you'll be reading and writing to the same drive. It should be a lot quicker if you have the 7z files on one drive and extract to another drive. There are a lot of small files in RetroBat and these can make the extraction slow down. When the process…
entry.content:
The extraction speed will depend on a few factors: CPU power, as it will need to perform the decompression algorithm.

Hard drive performance. Obviously an SSD or NVMe drive will be quicker than a traditional spinning drive. However it will also be slower if you just have a single drive, as you'll be reading and writing to the same drive. It should be a lot quicker if you have the 7z files on one drive and extract to another drive.

There are a lot of small files in RetroBat and these can make the extraction slow down. When the process reaches larger files it should speed up.

entry.title: Enabling autoresize at next boot
entry.summary: If you don't have a PC to plug you Batocera drive into or if it's an internal drive, you can do it all from the Batocera machine. Firstly make sure you have run the RGS Update Service to get our fix for the autoresize bug and rebooted at least once, then follow the steps below: Press F1 Start xTerm from Applications Run the following command: mount -o remount,rw /boot Then type: cd /boot Then type: vi batocera-boot.conf Use the arrow keys to move the cursor to the line with the autoresize option. Press the insert key to enter edit mode.
entry.content:
If you don't have a PC to plug you Batocera drive into or if it's an internal drive, you can do it all from the Batocera machine.

Firstly make sure you have run the RGS Update Service to get our fix for the autoresize bug and rebooted at least once, then follow the steps below:

Press F1 Start xTerm from Applications Run the following command:
mount -o remount,rw /boot

Then type:
cd /boot

Then type: vi batocera-boot.conf

Use the arrow keys to move the cursor to the line with the autoresize option.
Press the insert key to enter edit mode. Delete the # from the start of the line amd make sure the value is "true"
Press the Esc key.

Now type :
wq
to exit and save the file.

Then type:
reboot

This can also be done remotely from a PC via SSH using Putty.

entry.title: Hypseus SINGE (singe)
entry.content:
for Batocera and Retrobat

Hypseus SINGE, Somewhat Interactive Nostalgic Game Engine, (named after the dragon from Dragon's Lair) is the logical evolution of the Daphne emulator, which uses a Lua-based scripting system to quickly simulate LaserDisc games or create completely new games based on video files! The language is easy to learn, very powerful and fast. All the functions needed to develop your own game are available through a simple application programming interface (API).

The package includes:

91 games (~109 GB)

Go to download    

Many Thanks to g-spawn for reaching out to the comunity and putting together this pack! Thnx RapsterUK for creating the YT video. 

Hypseus is a fork of Matt Ownby's Daphne.
A program to play laserdisc arcade games on a PC, Mac or Raspberry Pi.
This version includes Singe support for Fan Made and American Laser Games.

How to Install:
1. Drag and drop the "singe" folder to the "roms" directory
2. If asked to overwrite say yes to all

entry.title: Daphne (daphne)
entry.content:
for Batocera and Retrobat

DAPHNE is an arcade emulator application that emulates a variety of laserdisc video games with the intent of preserving these games and making the play experience as faithful to the originals as possible. The developer calls DAPHNE the "First Ever Multiple Arcade Laserdisc Emulator" ("FEMALE"). It derives its name from Princess Daphne, the heroine of Dragon's Lair.

The package includes:

19 games (~15 GB)

Go to download    

How to Install:
1. Remove roms\daphne
2. Drag and drop the "daphne" folder to the "roms" directory

entry.title: Pinball M (pinballm)
entry.content:
for Batocera and Retrobat

 

Get ready to tilt into terror. The new horror-inspired pinball platform for fearless players. Prove your skills on the most sinister, gory, and badass tables ever brought to life.

Spine-chilling features:

- Wrath of the Elder Gods: Director’s Cut - experience the eldritch horror unrestricted for free
- A library of brand new, never-before-seen tables filled with fear and carnage
- Thrilling competition
- Zen Studios’ ultimate pinball simulation

Press start and flip for your life!

The package includes:

7 tables (~7 GB)

Go to download

How to install:
Drag and drop the "pinballm" folder into the 'roms' directory and Enjoy!

Correct functioning of the system requires execution of the last pixn-update available for the system

If when you run any of the PinballFX systems (PinballFX, PinballFX 2, PinballFX 3 or Pinball M) and you find only a few of the tables are unlocked. It could be down to a couple of things:

1. Make sure that your RetroBat folder is excluded from real-time scanning within your Anti-Virus software. Also check that it hasn't already removed or quarantined any files from those systems. If it has, restore them or copy them again from the downloaded ROMpack.

2. If you have the official Steam client installed on your machine, make sure it is NOT running when trying to run these systems. Make sure it is fully closed including from the system tray.

3. To confirm no files are missing, compare the contents of the downloaded ROMpack against what is in your /rom/system-name folder.

For those running Windows Defender, here's how to add an exclusion. I personally exclude the RetroBat folder and the folder I download the packs to:Link.

entry.title: Pinball FX3 (pinballfx3)
entry.content:
for Batocera and Retrobat

 

Pinball FX 3 is a pinball simulator video game developed and published by Zen Studios and released for Microsoft Windows, Xbox One, PlayStation 4 in September 2017 and then released for the Nintendo Switch in December 2017.

Pinball FX 3 allows players to play one of several simulated pinball tables, and includes online scoreboard support for informal competition with other players. The game is aimed to provide a more engaging multiplayer experience than previous titles; the game will provide support for asynchronous competitive multiplayer options, and tournament-style play. There will be shared leaderboards and multiplayer options among platforms, although PlayStation 4 players can only compete with users playing through Steam on Windows due to Sony's initial decision to prohibit cross-platform play between its PlayStation 4 and other consoles.

The package includes:

100 tables (~10 GB)

Go to download

How to install:
Drag and drop the "pinballfx3" folder into the 'roms' directory and Enjoy!

Correct functioning of the system requires execution of the last pixn-update available for the system

If when you run any of the PinballFX systems (PinballFX, PinballFX 2, PinballFX 3 or Pinball M) and you find only a few of the tables are unlocked. It could be down to a couple of things:

1. Make sure that your RetroBat folder is excluded from real-time scanning within your Anti-Virus software. Also check that it hasn't already removed or quarantined any files from those systems. If it has, restore them or copy them again from the downloaded ROMpack.

2. If you have the official Steam client installed on your machine, make sure it is NOT running when trying to run these systems. Make sure it is fully closed including from the system tray.

3. To confirm no files are missing, compare the contents of the downloaded ROMpack against what is in your /rom/system-name folder.

For those running Windows Defender, here's how to add an exclusion. I personally exclude the RetroBat folder and the folder I download the packs to:Link.
